children.name: to publicly tell a lot of people about sth
say
children.definition: /seɪ/  to say sth publicly or officially, using spoken or written words:nói

children.name: say (that)
examples: ▪ The President said he had no intention of resigning.
▪ The rules say that sports shoes must be worn in the gym at all times.

children.name: say what/how/who etc
examples: ▪ The police are refusing to say where Davies is being held.

children.name: report
children.definition: to give people news about what is happening, in newspapers, on television, or on the radio: tường thuật, tường trình, đưa tin
examples: The local newspaper has reported several cases of meningitis in the area.

children.name: report (that)
examples: Our foreign correspondent reports that conditions in the refugee camps are filthy and overcrowded.

children.name: report on
examples: She was sent to Washington to report on the presidential elections.

children.name: state
children.definition: /steɪt/  formal to say something publicly or officially, especially in clear, definite language:chỉ ra
examples: ▪ The government needs to clearly state its policy on possible military action.

children.name: state that: chỉ ra rằng
examples: ▪ The law states that you are innocent until proved guilty.
▪ Justice Cohen stated clearly that no further action would be taken.

children.name: publicize
children.definition: /publiciseBritish  to use the newspapers, television etc to provide information about something such as a new product, a special event, or an important subject, because you want everyone to know about it: công khai
examples: ▪ She did a series of interviews to publicize her new book.
▪ Orlov spent seven years in prison for publicizing human-rights violations.

children.name: well publicizedmentioned a lot in newspapers, on television etc công khai rộng rãi
examples: ▪ The parade was well publicized, and thousands of people came to see it.

children.name: declare
children.definition: to state officially and publicly that a particular situation exists or that sth is true :thông cáo, tuyên bố
examples: A state of emergency has been declared.
declare that
The court declared that Brown’s case should be reviewed.
declare sb/sth (to be) sb/sth
Several countries wanted Antarctica to be declared a ‘world park’.
The city was declared to be in a state of siege.
I declare you man and wife.
declare sb insane/unfit/a traitor etc
In the last century, mothers of illegitimate babies could be declared insane.
After nearly forty years’ membership, the Communist party declared him a traitor.
declare an amnesty/a state of emergenc
declare sth illegal/invalid etc
The war was declared illegal by the International Court of Justice.
Mr Steel has beendeclared bankrupt(= it has been officially stated that he cannot pay his debts).
We celebrate September 16, the day when Mexicodeclared independencefrom Spain(= officially stated that it was no longer ruled by Spain ).

children.name: announce
children.definition: to officially tell people about sth, especially about a plan or a decision, in a written or spoken public statement:thông báo, tuyên bố
examples: They announced their engagement in ‘The Times’.

children.name: announce a decision/intention/plan
examples: The government has announced plans to create 10,000 new jobs.

children.name: announce your engagementto officially tell people that you are going to get married
examples: They announced their engagement last year, but have still not set a date for their wedding.

children.name: announce sth to sb
examples: Cordon announced his resignation to staff members on Wednesday.

children.name: announce (that)
examples: The Spanish government announced that it would invest over $14,000 million in the Latin American region.
The Prime Minister has just announced there is to be a General Election next month.
A government spokesman announced that the hostages had been released.

children.name: it was announced that
examples: At the end of their meeting,it was announced thatan agreement had been reached.

children.name: make a statement
children.definition: make/issue a statement to say or write sth publicly in order to tell people what you intend to do, what your opinion is etc - use this especially about politicians, business leaders, and other people in authority:
examples: ▪ The party’s environment spokesman intends to make a statement either today or tomorrow.
▪ The president’s press corps issued this statement today.

children.name: lay down
children.definition: /ˌleɪ ˈdaʊn/  to officially state the rules that say what is allowed in a particular situation:
examples: đưa ra
lay down something: đưa ra cái gì
▪ The new law lays down strict rules about the way guns may be bought and sold.
lay down that: chỉ ra rằng
▪ It is laid down in the club rules that guests are not allowed in unless they are accompanied by a club member.

children.name: be worded
children.definition: if something such as an official statement or document is worded in a particular way, the speaker or writer has deliberately chosen their words in that way to get a particular effect: được diễn tả, viết là
examples: ▪ His speech to the police officers about racial violence had to be very carefully worded.
▪ The Defence Secretary made a public statement about the crisis, but it was worded in such a way as to give very little information.

children.name: statement
children.definition: sth you say or write, especially publicly or officially, to let people know your intentions or opinions, or to record facts : phát biểu, tuyên bố, trình bày
examples: In an official statement, she formally announced her resignation.
statement on/about
the Prime Minister’s recent statements on Europe

children.name: make a statement
children.definition: say something, especially in public
examples: The minister will make a statement on the matter tomorrow.

children.name: give a statement
children.definition: make a statement, especially to the police
examples: He gave a statement to the police.

children.name: issue/release/put out a statement
children.definition: give a written statement to newspapers, TV etc
examples: The Russian Foreign Ministry issued a short statement saying the meeting was ‘useful’.

children.name: take/get a statement from somebody
examples: I asked the police why they didn’t take a statement from me four years ago.

children.name: withdraw your statement
children.definition: say that a statement you gave is not true
examples: She later withdrew her statement.

children.name: a short/brief statement
examples: Police last night issued a brief statement about the incident.

children.name: a clear statement
children.definition: giving an opinion clearly
examples: The article was a clear statement of his beliefs.

children.name: a sweeping statement
children.definition: one that is too general
examples: Researchers do not want to make any sweeping statements at this stage.

children.name: a false/misleading statement
children.definition: one that is not true
examples: She is accused of making false statements to obtain a passport.

children.name: an official statement
examples: The company is expected to make an official statement tomorrow.

children.name: a formal statement
children.definition: one you must sign to show that it is true
examples: You will be asked to make a formal statement.

children.name: a public statement
children.definition: one made in public
examples: We will be making no public statements about the matter.

children.name: a written statement
examples: One neighbour said in a written statement that she often heard a baby ‘crying for help’.

children.name: a prepared statement
children.definition: one that is prepared and then read out
examples: His solicitor read a prepared statement on his behalf.

children.name: a sworn statement
children.definition: one that you officially promise is true
examples: The reports were based on sworn statements of graduates of the terrorist training camp.

children.name: a policy statement
children.definition: one that explains a government policy
examples: In his first major policy statement to Parliament he promised to end corruption in public life.

children.name: a mission statement
children.definition: one in which an organization states its aims
examples: The role of a mission statement is to focus on the purpose of the organization.

children.name: announcement
children.definition: a public or official statement telling people what has happened or what will happen : thông báo
examples: The minister made the announcement at a news conference.
announcement about
an important announcement about tax increases
announcement that
They heard the announcement that the mayor was resigning.

children.name: make/issue an announcement
examples: The next day an announcement was issued to staff, saying the company would be closing.|The government issued an announcement saying that it was not prepared to negotiate with terrorists.

children.name: hear an announcement
examples: Everyone was shocked when they heard the announcement.

children.name: welcome an announcement
children.definition: say that you are pleased about it
examples: Environmental groups welcomed the announcement.

children.name: greet an announcementformal
children.definition: react to it in a particular way
examples: The announcement was. greeted with cheers on both sides of the House.

children.name: an announcement comes
children.definition: it happens
examples: His announcement came after two days of peace talks.

children.name: a formal announcement
examples: A formal announcement will be made in Parliament.

children.name: an official announcement
examples: No official announcement is expected until next year.

children.name: a surprise announcement/an unexpected announcement
examples: The Senator made the surprise announcement that he will not be seeking re-election.

children.name: a dramatic announcement
children.definition: sudden and important
examples: The dramatic announcement came after a cabinet meeting on Tuesday.

children.name: a further announcement
examples: A further announcement will be made in the near future.

children.name: declaration
children.definition: an important official statement, especially about what a government or organization intends to do:
examples: a ceasefire declaration
Under Islamic law it was possible to divorce by simple declaration.
declaration of
the declaration of war
declaration of war/independence/intent etc
On the 19th of July a declaration of war was delivered in Berlin.
declaration that
They issued a declaration that it will be attempting to take over another three British companies.
make a declaration
Members of Parliament must make a declaration of their business interests.
As witnesses to the accident, we were asked to make written declarations of what we had seen.

children.name: declare
children.definition: a)to state on an official government form how much money you have earned, what property you own etc : khai báo
examples: Nothing to declare.
All tips are counted as part of your earnings and must be declared.
You have to declare any earnings over a certain amount.

children.name: b)to tell a customs official that you are carrying goods on which you should pay tax when you enter a country
examples: Goods to declare.
